head.title: DataBank; Dow and S.& P. End the Week at Record Highs

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: DataBank; Dow and S.& P. End the Week at Record Highs

block.p: It was a short but glorious week for the stock market, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closing on Friday at record highs.

On Friday, a government report showed a surge in job creation in May. And an inflation gauge favored by the Federal Reserve -- the core personal consumption expenditure deflator -- rose in April at the relatively modest annualized rate of 2 percent.
It was a short but glorious week for the stock market, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closing on Friday at record highs.

On Friday, a government report showed a surge in job creation in May. And an inflation gauge favored by the Federal Reserve -- the core personal consumption expenditure deflator -- rose in April at the relatively modest annualized rate of 2 percent.
Wal-Mart Stores gained 6.1 percent for the week, the best performance among the Dow industrials. The company said it would repurchase $15 billion of its shares.

Archstone-Smith, the real estate investment trust, rose 20.4 percent, the best weekly performance in the S.& P. 500. Archstone-Smith is being acquired for $22.2 billion by Tishman-Speyer and Lehman Brothers.

The market was closed on Monday for Memorial Day. For the week, the Dow rose 160.83 points, or 1.2 percent, to close at 13,668.11. The S.& P. 500 gained 20.61 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 1,536.34. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 56.73 points, or 2.2 percent, to close at 2,613.92. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 4.95 percent from 4.86 percent the previous week.
